channel.title: My First Program

item.title: My First Program
item.dc:creator: @whackatre Whackatre
item.description:
@whackatre wrote:

[quote="_s, post:19, topic:442755"][quote author=whackatre link=topic=545440.msg4000157#msg4000157 date=1337877393]

[quote author=_s link=topic=545440.msg3998819#msg3998819 date=1337648898]

I’ve never really trusted the System.nanoTime() method. I can run the exact same bit of code, and get different result every time (between 220ns, and 5000ns)
[/quote]granted, it’s a pretty shit way of benchmarking anything really

So then what method do you recommend to test out efficiency?

And if efficiency’s not all about speed, what is it really about?

Oh and I’ve been looking at this http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_O_notation after doing some research on efficiency of algorithms, and I don’t get it at all, can somebody simplify that for me? ;D
[/quote]efficiency can be deduced by analysing an algorithm and following the flow to see how many steps it takes. also, measuring such mundane things and their performance is stupid, end of; microbenchmarking won’t get you anywhere, you’re better off ignoring the performance of algorithms individually and instead use a profiler to figure out where your bottlenecks may be.

also efficiency is just a general thing, you get lots of different types of efficiency ie. time or space efficiency, it’s just a metric of an algorithm’s resource usage, where the resource can be space or time or something else. usually, time efficiency of an algorithm is a decent indicator to how well the algorithm performs speed-wise, but this is not always the case as some huge operations can take ridiculous amounts of time to compute yet analysis may yield that the operation actually has a low time complexity.

also, since that wikipedia article is inaccessible to anyone that doesn’t understand such formalities, i recommend reading http://rob-bell.net/2009/06/a-beginners-guide-to-big-o-notation/ for a basic idea and move on to learning about logarithmic complexity once you have the basics down.[/quote]

Thank you for that link, it was definitely simpler to read than the Wikipedia article. I’ll look further into that after exams.

Read full topic

item.title: My First Program
item.dc:creator: @purestmage74 purestmage74
item.description:
@purestmage74 wrote:

sp11k3t3ht3rd:

Instead of having that big if statement, you could have a switch statement. Read about it here: http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/java/nutsandbolts/switch.html Good job though!

Referring to his post:

	  public static void main(String[] args) throws InterruptedException {
          String name = "WhileCounter ";
          long currentTime = System.nanoTime();
		for (int i = 1; i < 101; i++) {
			switch (i) { // Begin 'switch' statement.
			case 10:
				System.out.println(name + "has looped 10 times");
				break;
			case 20:
				System.out.println(name + "has looped 20 times");
				break;
			case 30:
				System.out.println(name + "has looped 30 times");
				break;
			case 40:
				System.out.println(name + "has looped 40 times");
				break;
			case 50:
				System.out.println(name + "has looped 50 times");
				break;
			case 100:
				System.out.println(name + "has looped 100 times");
				break;
				
				default:
				// Could have it return a default.
					break;
			} // end 'switch' statement.
		}
		System.out.println("Took " + (System.nanoTime() - currentTime) + "ns to finish.");
	}

Didn’t bother reading the date, so if i’m grave digging (haven’t been on in weeks), sorry.
Besides my post, good job for your first program :).
Best way to learn java is REALLY messing with all the ‘if, else, try, catch, boolean, int, String’ etc.

Read full topic

item.title: My First Program
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“whackatre, post:18, topic:442755”][quote author=_s link=topic=545440.msg3998819#msg3998819 date=1337648898]

I’ve never really trusted the System.nanoTime() method. I can run the exact same bit of code, and get different result every time (between 220ns, and 5000ns)
[/quote]granted, it’s a pretty shit way of benchmarking anything really

So then what method do you recommend to test out efficiency?

And if efficiency’s not all about speed, what is it really about?

Oh and I’ve been looking at this http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Big_O_notation after doing some research on efficiency of algorithms, and I don’t get it at all, can somebody simplify that for me? ;D[/quote]efficiency can be deduced by analysing an algorithm and following the flow to see how many steps it takes. also, measuring such mundane things and their performance is stupid, end of; microbenchmarking won’t get you anywhere, you’re better off ignoring the performance of algorithms individually and instead use a profiler to figure out where your bottlenecks may be.

also efficiency is just a general thing, you get lots of different types of efficiency ie. time or space efficiency, it’s just a metric of an algorithm’s resource usage, where the resource can be space or time or something else. usually, time efficiency of an algorithm is a decent indicator to how well the algorithm performs speed-wise, but this is not always the case as some huge operations can take ridiculous amounts of time to compute yet analysis may yield that the operation actually has a low time complexity.

also, since that wikipedia article is inaccessible to anyone that doesn’t understand such formalities, i recommend reading http://rob-bell.net/2009/06/a-beginners-guide-to-big-o-notation/ for a basic idea and move on to learning about logarithmic complexity once you have the basics down.

item.title: My First Program
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“eyeownyew, post:14, topic:442755”][quote author=_s link=topic=545440.msg3998723#msg3998723 date=1337641076]

@Eyeownyew: That didn’t change a thing.

I told you to implement something similar, not use my exact code. And it shouldn’t change the outcome, just the efficiency/look of the code
[/quote]plz dont throw around the word efficient, thanks

Oh right my bad, because I was wrong (nope):
Regular

[code=java]public class WhileCounter {

    public static void main(String[] args) throws InterruptedException {

            String name = "WhileCounter ";
			long currentTime = System.nanoTime();
			
            for (int i = 1; i < 101; i++) {
                    if (i == 10)
                            System.out.println(name+ "has looped 10 times");
                    if (i == 20)
                            System.out.println(name+ "has looped 20 times");
                    if (i == 30)
                            System.out.println(name+ "has looped 30 times");
                    if (i == 40)
                            System.out.println(name+ "has looped 40 times");
                    if (i == 50)
                            System.out.println(name+ "has looped 50 times");
                    if (i == 100) {
                            System.out.println(name+ "has looped 100 times");
                            Thread.interrupted();
                    }
            }
			System.out.println("Took "+(System.nanoTime() - currentTime)+"ns to finish.");
    }

}[/code]
Modulo

[code=java]public class WhileCounterModulo {

    public static void main(String[] args) throws InterruptedException {

            String name = "WhileCounter ";
			long currentTime = System.nanoTime();
            for (int i = 1; i < 101; i++) {
                    if (i%10 == 0) {
                            System.out.println(name+ "has looped "+i+" times.");
					}
            }
			System.out.println("Took "+(System.nanoTime() - currentTime)+"ns to finish.");
    }

}[/code]

Regular:

WhileCounter has looped 10 times WhileCounter has looped 20 times WhileCounter has looped 30 times WhileCounter has looped 40 times WhileCounter has looped 50 times WhileCounter has looped 100 times Took 29292829ns to finish.
Modulo

WhileCounter has looped 10 times. WhileCounter has looped 20 times. WhileCounter has looped 30 times. WhileCounter has looped 40 times. WhileCounter has looped 50 times. WhileCounter has looped 60 times. WhileCounter has looped 70 times. WhileCounter has looped 80 times. WhileCounter has looped 90 times. WhileCounter has looped 100 times. Took 3543188ns to finish.

Notice that it took about a tenth of the time, and actually prints to the console more often.

Bitch please.[/quote]thank you for proving my point, you don’t understand efficiency obviously (hint: efficiency isn’t always speed) and since each loop is an O(n) operation for all we care, both of these loops are of equivalent algorithmic efficiency. also, amusingly enough the poor speed of the old version is due to the vast amounts of comparisons being made (easily fixed)

updated for else-if usage

[code=java]public class WhileCounter {

    public static void main(String[] args) throws InterruptedException {

            String name = "WhileCounter ";
                            long currentTime = System.nanoTime();
                           
            for (int i = 1; i < 101; i++) {
                    if (i == 10)
                            System.out.println(name+ "has looped 10 times");
                    else if (i == 20)
                            System.out.println(name+ "has looped 20 times");
                    else if (i == 30)
                            System.out.println(name+ "has looped 30 times");
                    else if (i == 40)
                            System.out.println(name+ "has looped 40 times");
                    else if (i == 50)
                            System.out.println(name+ "has looped 50 times");
                    else if (i == 100) {
                            System.out.println(name+ "has looped 100 times");
                            Thread.interrupted();
                    }
            }
                            System.out.println("Took "+(System.nanoTime() - currentTime)+"ns to finish.");
    }

}[/code]

runspeed of the updated for else-if on my machine

WhileCounter has looped 10 times WhileCounter has looped 20 times WhileCounter has looped 30 times WhileCounter has looped 40 times WhileCounter has looped 50 times WhileCounter has looped 100 times Took 438068ns to finish.

whereas yours, on my machine, gives

WhileCounter has looped 10 times. WhileCounter has looped 20 times. WhileCounter has looped 30 times. WhileCounter has looped 40 times. WhileCounter has looped 50 times. WhileCounter has looped 60 times. WhileCounter has looped 70 times. WhileCounter has looped 80 times. WhileCounter has looped 90 times. WhileCounter has looped 100 times. Took 1341538ns to finish.

so, what was that?

Bitch please. also try again moron

Read full topic

}[/code]

WhileCounter has looped 10 times WhileCounter has looped 20 times WhileCounter has looped 30 times WhileCounter has looped 40 times WhileCounter has looped 50 times WhileCounter has looped 100 times Took 29292829ns to finish.

WhileCounter has looped 10 times. WhileCounter has looped 20 times. WhileCounter has looped 30 times. WhileCounter has looped 40 times. WhileCounter has looped 50 times. Notice that it took about a tenth of the time, and actually prints to the console more often.

Bitch please.

item.title: My First Program
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

en.wikipedia.org

Modulo operation

In computing, the modulo operation finds the remainder after division of one number by another (sometimes called modulus). Given two positive numbers, a (the dividend) and n (the divisor), a modulo n (abbreviated as a mod n) is the remainder of the Euclidean division of a by n. For example, the expression "5 mod 2" would evaluate to 1 because 5 divided by 2 leaves a quotient of 2 and a remainder of 1, while "9 mod 3" would evaluate to 0 because the division of 9 by 3 has a quotient of 3 and leave...

item.title: My First Program
item.dc:creator: @Skyro Arbe
item.description:
@Skyro wrote:

Hey, well I’ve made my first code out for RSPS and I’m pretty proud of myself.

What this does, is simply count from 1-100, each second it counts a number. When it reaches, 10, 20, 30, 40, 50 it imprints a little message to tell you how many seconds it’s gone for and has a 5 second break between each 10 seconds. Then when it reaches 100 it will stop, but if it goes pass 100 I’ve made it imprint an error and to stop.

public class WhileCounter {

	/**
	 * @name WhileCounter.java
	 * @author Skyro
	 * 
	 * @param args
	 * @throws InterruptedException
	 * 
	 */

	public static void main(String[] args) throws InterruptedException {

		String name = "WhileCounter ";

		for (int i = 1; i < 101; i++) {
			System.out.println("Number: " + i + ".");
			Rest(1);

			if (i == 10) {
				System.out.println(name
						+ "has looped 10 times and is taking a break...");
				Rest(5);
			} else if (i == 20) {
				System.out.println(name
						+ "has looped 20 times and is taking a break...");
				Rest(5);
			} else if (i == 30) {
				System.out.println(name
						+ "has looped 30 times and is taking a break...");
				Rest(5);
			} else if (i == 40) {
				System.out.println(name
						+ "has looped 40 times and is taking a break...");
				Rest(5);
			} else if (i == 50) {
				System.out.println(name
						+ "has looped 50 times and is taking a break...");
				Rest(5);
			} else if (i == 100) {
				System.out.println(name
						+ "has looped 100 times and has stopped.");
				Thread.interrupted();
			} else if (i >= 101) {
				System.out.println(name
						+ "has encountered and error and has been stopped.");
				Thread.interrupted();
			}
		}
	}

	public static void Rest(int seconds) {
		try {
			Thread.sleep(seconds * 1000);
		} catch (Exception e) {
			e.printStackTrace();
			System.out.println("Counter has slept for " +

			seconds + " seconds.");
		}
	}
}

Pastebin: http://pastebin.com/isaXKNmU

Read full topic
